message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vertebral burst fracture at the level of T11 may cause damage to the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensation. This may result in impaired pain and temperature sensation up to T10-T11. However, the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, which carries fine touch and vibration sense, usually remains intact in these types of injuries. Therefore, preserved fine touch is the most likely finding in this patient. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are associated with upper motor neuron lesions, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vertebral burst fracture at T11 likely damages the dorsal funiculus, where the fine touch pathway is located. The impairment of pain and temperature sensation up to T10-T11 further reinforces this conclusion. Crude touch is carried by the spinothalamic pathway, which is separate from the fine touch pathway. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are more commonly associated with spinal cord injuries at thoracic and cervical levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with spinal cord injury at the T10-11 level. Preservation of fine touch suggests that the dorsal columns, which transmit fine touch, are not affected. Presence of flaccid paralysis and impaired sensation suggest involvement of the lower motor neurons and spinothalamic tract, respectively. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are more commonly seen in upper motor neuron lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has suffered a spinal cord injury at T11, which is a level where fine touch is preserved but crude touch, pain, and temperature sensation are impaired. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are more commonly seen with injuries at higher levels, such as T6 or above, but may occur at lower levels in some cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s sensory deficits suggest a complete spinal cord injury, which is consistent with a vertebral burst fracture at the level of T11. Fine touch is carried by the dorsal columns, which are primarily located in the posterior part of the spinal cord. Crude touch and pain sensation are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are more anterior. Hyperreflexia is a characteristic feature of spinal cord injury above the level of the lesion, and bladder dysfunction is common in spinal cord injury involving the lower part of the spinal cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vertebral burst fracture at T11 is likely to cause damage to the dorsal columns and spinothalamic tracts. Therefore, fine touch and proprioception are likely to be preserved while crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations are impaired below the level of injury. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction may occur with higher levels of spinal cord injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging suggest a spinal cord injury, specifically at the level of T11. Fine touch and proprioception fibers from the periphery enter the spinal cord dorsal column medial lemniscus pathway on the same side, so it's likely they are preserved here. Crude touch, pain, and temperature travel up the spinothalamic tract and cross over to the opposite side, so they would be impaired. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are common lower motor neuron signs, which are not present here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vertebral burst fracture at the level of T11 has caused compression on the spinal cord resulting in lower extremity flaccid paralysis and impaired pain and temperature sensation up to T10-T11. Fine touch sensation is usually preserved in this type of injury as it is carried by the dorsal columns, which are not as affected as the spinothalamic tracts, which carry crude touch sensation. Hyperreflexia and bladder dysfunction are more commonly seen in upper motor neuron lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the vertebral burst fracture suggest spinal cord injury. Fine touch is carried by the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, which are not affected in this level of injury. Crude touch, pain, and temperature sensation are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are affected in this level of injury. Hyperreflexia is seen in upper motor neuron lesions, but this is a lower motor neuron lesion. Bladder function is affected in cauda equina syndrome, which is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a burst fracture of the vertebral body at T11, which can cause damage to the dorsal columns of the spinal cord. The dorsal columns are responsible for fine touch sensation, so preserved fine touch is the most likely finding. Impaired pain and temperature sensation suggests damage to the spinothalamic tract. Flaccid paralysis indicates damage to lower motor neurons. Normal vibration sense suggests intact dorsal column/medial lemniscal pathway. Hyperreflexia suggests upper motor neuron damage. Abnormal bladder function suggests damage at S2-S4 spinal cord levels.
